title: Games with Three Layers - Individual, Group, and Society
description: Understanding how individually rational choices can lead to collectively bad outcomes, and the mechanisms we use to promote cooperation across different scales of organization

promptInstructions.focus: Explore tension between individual rationality and collective outcomes. Blake should question cooperation mechanisms as stifling individual freedom. Drew should argue people can be naturally cooperative. Professor Hartwell should push back gently but firmly when students disagree with him.

breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand how individually rational choices can lead to collectively bad outcomes

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, you've been questioning whether our theories actually explain human behavior. Fair enough. But consider this: what happens when everyone in a group acts purely in their own self-interest?

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: Well, that should work out fine, shouldn't it? If everyone does what's best for themselves, the group benefits from everyone being better off. That's how markets work.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: But that's not always how it works in practice. Think about traffic jams - everyone wants to get where they're going faster, but when everyone tries to cut ahead or change lanes constantly, it slows everyone down.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: I'm willing to be wrong, Blake. But let me give you a concrete example. You're at a concert, and you can't quite see the stage because of the person in front of you.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: So you stand up to get a better view. That makes perfect sense for you individually.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Right. Ri-ri-ri-ri-right. But what happens next?

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: The person behind you can't see anymore, so they stand up too. And then the person behind them, and so on.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: And eventually everyone's standing, which is less comfortable for everyone, and the people in back still can't see any better than when everyone was sitting.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Now Blake, each person made a perfectly rational individual choice, but the collective outcome made everyone worse off. This is what game theorists call a social dilemma.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: But couldn't people just agree to all stay seated? Why does it have to turn out badly?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: I'm not trying to be difficult, Drew. But about this I would say - even if everyone agrees to stay seated, each individual still has an incentive to defect from that agreement. The first person to stand gets a much better view, and there's no immediate consequence.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: It's like a systems problem where the individual optimization conflicts with the system optimization. The feedback loops push toward the worse collective outcome.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: This goes back to what Hobbes wrote about in Leviathan - without some authority to enforce agreements, people will inevitably pursue their immediate self-interest even when it leads to worse outcomes for all.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: But wait - are you saying people are inherently selfish? That seems pretty cynical about human nature.

breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand how societies develop mechanisms to encourage cooperation and the tension between individual freedom and collective coordination

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: Blake raises a good point. I see people being cooperative all the time. People hold doors for strangers, they volunteer, they donate to charity. Why does game theory assume everyone's selfish?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Right. Ri-ri-ri-ri-right. But on the other hand, Drew, game theory doesn't assume everyone's selfish. It focuses on situations where individual and collective interests diverge. The cooperative behavior you're describing often requires what we call cooperation mechanisms.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: What do you mean by cooperation mechanisms? That sounds like a euphemism for forcing people to do things they don't want to do.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, cooperation mechanisms are ways that groups change individual incentives so that cooperation becomes more attractive than defection. They don't necessarily involve force.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: There are informal mechanisms too, right? Like reputation and social pressure. If everyone knows you're the person who always stands up first at concerts, people might avoid going with you.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: Exactly what Mill was getting at in On Liberty - society has many ways of enforcing conformity that don't involve government coercion. Social ostracism can be just as powerful as legal penalties.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: See, that's exactly what I'm worried about. Whether it's laws or social pressure, these cooperation mechanisms end up stifling individual freedom. You're basically saying people have to conform or face punishment.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: But Blake, what about cooperation that comes naturally? When my neighbor's house flooded last year, half the street showed up to help move their furniture. Nobody forced them to do it.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Drew, I'm willing to be wrong about this. But what you're describing may actually prove the point. Your neighbors helped because they live in a small community where reputation matters, where they might need help themselves someday. Those are informal cooperation mechanisms at work.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: Haidt says humans are ninety percent chimp and ten percent bee. Most of the time we're focused on our own individual interests, like chimps. But we also have this capacity for group cooperation, like bees in a hive, that kicks in under certain circumstances.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: So we're naturally selfish most of the time, but occasionally we act cooperatively? That doesn't sound very optimistic.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: I think you're missing the point, Blake. The fact that we have any cooperative instincts at all sets us apart from most other species. We just need to figure out how to bring out more of the bee and less of the chimp.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: But that's precisely where cooperation mechanisms come in. They're not necessarily about forcing cooperation - they're about creating conditions where our cooperative instincts can flourish.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: Or they're about suppressing our individual autonomy in favor of group conformity. It depends on your perspective.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: I'm not trying to be difficult, Blake. But about this I would say - both perspectives have merit. The question is understanding when cooperation mechanisms enhance human flourishing and when they constrain it. And that depends partly on the scale we're talking about.

breakpoints.subheading: From Dunbar's Number to Three Layers of Society
breakpoints.learningObjective: Understand how different scales of social organization require different cooperation mechanisms and create competing loyalties

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: The scale issue brings us to Dunbar's number. Casey, tell us about that.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: Dunbar found that primates' brain size correlates with the size of social groups they can manage. For humans, that number is roughly 150 people - the maximum group size where everyone can know everyone else personally.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: And this creates a natural break point in how cooperation mechanisms work. Below 150 people, you can rely on informal mechanisms - gossip, reputation, personal relationships. Above that, you need formal systems.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: Like the difference between a small business where everyone knows each other versus a large corporation that needs employee handbooks and organization charts.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Arnold Kling describes this as sub-Dunbar versus super-Dunbar organization. But here's where it gets complicated - we all operate simultaneously at three different layers.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: What do you mean by three layers?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Think about your own life, Blake. You make decisions as an individual, but you're also part of various small groups - family, friends, maybe a sports team or club. And you're also part of larger institutions - your university, your city, your country.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: So the individual layer, the sub-Dunbar group layer, and the super-Dunbar institutional layer. And what's optimal for one layer might not be optimal for another.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: That's a recipe for moral conflict. What if your family expects you to help them in ways that break the law? Or what if following the law means betraying your friends?

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: We see this all the time. Police officers who know their colleagues are corrupt but feel loyalty to their unit. Or people who want to report tax evasion but don't want to get their neighbors in trouble.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: And cooperation mechanisms can become too strong or too weak at any layer. If individual incentives dominate, groups fall apart. If group loyalty becomes too strong, it can undermine larger institutions.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: So you're saying there's no perfect solution? We're always going to have these conflicts between different levels of loyalty?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: That's the challenge of human interdependence, Blake. Consider India's caste system - it provided strong group cooperation mechanisms, but at the cost of flexibility and fairness at the societal level.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: I'd argue caste is an informal system because it's enforced through social norms and group pressure, not written laws.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: But it involves very strict, explicit rules about who can marry whom, what jobs people can have, even who can touch whom. That sounds pretty formal to me.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: The caste system shows how cooperation mechanisms can be simultaneously informal and formal, and how they can solve problems at one layer while creating problems at another.

breakpoints.subheading: Balancing Individual Liberty, Group Solidarity, and Social Order
breakpoints.learningObjective: Explore the fundamental tension between individual freedom, group loyalty, and institutional authority in maintaining political stability

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Drew, you seem to believe people can be naturally cooperative. Is government even necessary?

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: I think strong communities can handle most problems without heavy-handed government intervention. If people feel connected to their neighbors and have a stake in their community's success, they'll cooperate voluntarily.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: But that's exactly what I'm worried about, Drew. Strong communities often mean conformity pressure and exclusion of anyone who's different. I'd rather have individual freedom protected by law than rely on community goodwill.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: I'm willing to be wrong, Drew. But strong communities can become insular and oppressive. Blake has a point about needing institutional protections for individual rights.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: Both Mill and Hobbes would say you're each capturing part of the truth. Mill worried about the tyranny of social opinion, but Hobbes understood that without some sovereign authority, you get the war of all against all.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: It's like we need cooperation mechanisms that can operate across all three layers simultaneously. Individual rights that protect against group tyranny, but also group solidarity that prevents pure individualism from fragmenting society.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: And institutional frameworks that can channel group cooperation constructively rather than letting it turn into tribal warfare. But how do we achieve that balance?

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: Maybe the key is making sure people's different group loyalties overlap and cross-cut each other. If I'm in multiple groups with different people, I can't just write off everyone who's not in my primary tribe.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: But institutions have to protect the right of individuals to exit groups that become oppressive. If you can't leave your family, your religion, or your community, then group solidarity becomes group tyranny.

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: There's also the question of which institutions get to make which decisions. Local communities might handle some cooperation problems well, but they're terrible at others - like environmental protection or preventing discrimination.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: Right, it's about matching the scale of the cooperation mechanism to the scale of the problem. Climate change requires global cooperation, but neighborhood noise complaints can be handled locally.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Right. Ri-ri-ri-ri-right. But on the other hand, different groups benefit from cooperation mechanisms at different scales. Local elites might prefer local control even when broader coordination would be more effective.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: And national politicians might prefer centralized control even when local solutions would work better and preserve more individual freedom.

dialogue.speaker: Drew
dialogue.text: So political stability requires somehow getting all these different interests to agree on a framework that none of them think is optimal?

dialogue.speaker: Casey
dialogue.text: That's the genius and the fragility of constitutional democracy. It creates a process for resolving these conflicts peacefully, but it only works if all the major players accept the legitimacy of the process.

dialogue.speaker: Avery
dialogue.text: And it has to evolve as circumstances change. The cooperation mechanisms that worked in a rural, agricultural society might not work in an urban, technological one.

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Which brings us back to human interdependence. We need each other to survive and thrive, but the forms that interdependence takes are constantly in tension.

dialogue.speaker: Blake
dialogue.text: So there's no final solution, just ongoing negotiation between competing values and interests?

dialogue.speaker: Professor Hartwell
dialogue.text: Blake, political order isn't a problem to be solved once and for all, but a dynamic balance to be maintained across time and changing circumstances.
